Video Labeler

class video_labeler.ActivityHandler(labeler_instance: Labeler)[source]

Bases: object

__init__(labeler_instance: Labeler)[source]
populate_data_table_point_activity(data: list, shortcut_keys: str)[source]

Handling point activity (writing once)

populate_data_table_time_window(data: list, shortcut_keys: str)[source]

As described in _handle_shortcuts() above, this function will handle time_window option. (writing twice) It checks if it is first time pressed or second time pressed for the time_window activity.

class video_labeler.AppFunctions(labeler_instance: Labeler)[source]

Bases: object

This class gives some functionality to the app. Every function can also be accessed within settings.py and bind to a shortcut.

__init__(labeler_instance: Labeler)[source]
delete_selected_rows()[source]

Will deleted selected row in the data tale

load_csv_data()[source]

If there are any safed files for the loaded video. It will open the csv file and convert it into the data_table. So you can switch between videos and still have the actual data.

plot_hotkeys()[source]

To get access to plot hotkeys within settings.json. Important to know here. It will also open the plotted hotkeys and write it into the logger.

save_csv()[source]

Is needed to hard-save the csv file. It saves the csv file even the table is not changed. Where write_csv_data() checks if the data_table was changed or not.

sort_data_table()[source]

Will sort the data table by the first column (in this case StartTime)

update_video_table()[source]

Will create the playlist as a table, so all the videos in the “videos” directory will be shown as a table. Disable edits for column 0 (Video).

write_csv_data()[source]

Will write the data to csv. Loading the values from data_table and saving the video_name.csv.

class video_labeler.HotkeyPlotter[source]

Bases: object

This class is for checking the hotkeys and creating a plot for all the available hotkeys to give an overview to the user. The user can instantly see all the available hotkeys and also to check if there are some duplicated hotkeys, which should be avoided.

__init__()[source]
load_and_plot()[source]

The whole process from loading until plotting the hotkeys.

class video_labeler.Labeler(application, parent=None)[source]

Bases: QMainWindow

This is the “main” class for the application. It brings everything together. Also loading classes:

  • MouseEventHandler() as mouse_event

  • Layout() as layout

  • AppFunctions() as app_functions

  • Logger() as logger

  • ActivityHandler() as activity_handler

Everything is set up here. Also loading the .json files and processing and binding them.a

__init__(application, parent=None)[source]
commands_mpv()[source]

All the commands defined in commands_mpv.json will be loaded and set for the mpv-player.

For more information, see: https://github.com/mpv-player/mpv/blob/master/etc/input.conf https://mpv.io/manual/stable/#command-interface

label_shortcuts()[source]

Will load the label_shortcuts.json file and process the shortcuts.

observe_time_position()[source]

Observing the time position and writing it into the playtime widget.

settings()[source]

Will load the settings.json file and process the settings, that are set up. Like the size of the window, or some other hotkeys etc.

class video_labeler.Layout(labeler_instance: Labeler)[source]

Bases: object

This class is for creating the app-layout of the widgets. No functionality, only widgets. If it’s needed to insert more widgets, should be done here. And can be accessed within Labeler class.

__init__(labeler_instance: Labeler)[source]
create_app_window() → tuple[QWidget, QGridLayout][source]

Will open the main-window and center it.

create_data_table() → tuple[QTableWidget, QScrollArea][source]

Here will be all the values, that are labeled as an overview

create_logger() → tuple[QWidget, QScrollArea, QGridLayout][source]

The logging window, to get some feedback, what is going on.

create_mpv_player() → tuple[QWidget, MPV][source]

Starting MPV-Player and putting in withing a Widget.

create_second_column_video_layout() → tuple[QWidget, QVBoxLayout][source]

Combining MPV-Player, Playing-Time, Video-Name and Time-Slider within one column.

create_splitter() → tuple[QSplitter, QSplitter][source]

To make it more user-friendly, there are some splitters. So the user can drag the windows to the size he wants to.

create_style()[source]

Styling the app. Making it more visual-friendly

create_time_slider() → QSlider[source]

Is like a slider within any video-player.

create_video_table() → tuple[QTableWidget, QScrollArea][source]

Creating a table for all videos within the folder “videos”.

class video_labeler.Logger(labeler_instance: Labeler)[source]

Bases: object

This class is creating some logging to inform the user what happens. The most important cases are handled here and will be written into the Logging window within the app.

__init__(labeler_instance: Labeler)[source]
append_logging(logg_type: str = 'Information', text: str = '', bg_color: str = '#333333', border_color: str = '#333333', text_2: str = '', ignore_if_tracked: bool = False)[source]

Easier way to append the logging activity. More understandable. Set ignore_if_tracked as True if you want to show it only once or if it already in the logging window. Then it won’t display.

get_logging_idx(act_idx: int, shortcut_keys: str) → int[source]

Needed for time_window activities. So if the shortcut was already pressed it will return the index of the list, else it returns None.

write_logger()[source]

Create Labels as a logging window within the GUI. Use “Information” as the first value within the logging_activity list. Just append this list somewhere with three values. or just use append_logging() instead of self.logging_activity.append(). Both ways are fine.

Example:

self.logging_activity.append([“Information”, “The data is saved to .csv”, “Check documentation for more Information”]) self.logger.write_logger() # Will write the appended logging

class video_labeler.MouseEventHandler(labeler_instance: Labeler)[source]

Bases: object

A helper class for handling all the events of Labeler class. Everything that happens with Mouse-Clicks is an Event in this case.

__init__(labeler_instance: Labeler)[source]
close_app(event: QCloseEvent)[source]

Custom close event. If data-table was changed it will ask the user, if he wants to save the actual data-table. Save, Discard or Cancel possible.

data_table_click(item: QTableWidgetItem)[source]

Handling a row click on the populated data table. If row StartTime is selected, it will go to the video with the StartTime. If EndTime, it will go there. If something else. It will go to StartTime

slider_move(event)[source]

Handling the slider mouse press event. So it acts like a normal slider for a video. For example, you can add self.player.pause = False at the end, and it will play the video after releasing the mouse. So some settings for the slider can be done here.

splitter_click()[source]

Update the sizes of widgets based on the size of the first element in the splitter.

video_table_click(item: QTableWidgetItem)[source]

Starting and playing a video, by clicking on the row of the video in the table (play_list)

video_labeler.start_app()[source]
